prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: In a recent study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. published in Physica A 564 (2021), Figure 2 illustrates each social layer of a multi-layer network. The nodes in the network represent individuals, with weighted connections indicating social contact that may lead to infection based on the edge weight (a probability value between 0 and 1). The first layer depicts home interactions, comprised of groups of varying sizes that are internally fully connected. These groups have no external connections, reflecting individual families as disconnected components. The distribution of family sizes in Argentina in 2009 is used to create each group, considering probabilities for family sizes ranging from 1 to 10 members. Therefore the probability of a family having ten persons is the sum of the larger sizes, the details of this distribution are given in Table 1. The first layer is then created following the family size distribution and ensuring that each family has at least one adult. Fig. 2(a) shows the structure of such a layer built for a
post_context: . A significant portion of the population in any country must engage in work or some form of economic activity, which involves interacting with others. This makes work a crucial aspect of social relationships, especially during an epidemic. To model work activity, we suggest a generic layer that connects individuals aged 18 to 59, representing 60% of the total population in Argentina. Due to the diverse range of jobs and companies, it is challenging to devise a connection rule that accurately mirrors the real world. In our study, we consider a common scenario with random groups ranging from 5 to 30 individuals, following a uniform distribution, and internally connected like the ''home'' layer. An illustration of this layer is depicted in Fig. 2(b) using n = 100. While nodes within a group are fully connected, the spread of the virus relies on the edge weights, as discussed in Section 3.1.1. Public transportation is vital in most cities but poses a risk during an epidemic due to the high volume of travelers who constantly move across geographical areas. Our third proposed layer represents these public transports catering to individuals without personal vehicles. In Argentina, the usage of public transport varies depending on the city size, with 64.98% in capitals and 35.89% in other cities [23], averaging about 1.2 hours daily. Here, we consider an average of 50% of the population between these two cases to participate in the ''transports'' layer. Random groups of sizes from 10 to 40 are formed and fully connected within each group.

prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: In a recent study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. published in Physica A 564 (2021), a multi-layer network model was proposed to represent social interactions. The model includes different social layers, with each layer consisting of nodes representing people and weighted connections indicating social contact that may lead to infection. The first layer represents home interactions, with groups of varying sizes based on Colombian family size distribution for 2010. The distribution considers family sizes from 1 to 10 members, ensuring that each family has at least one adult. Another important layer in the model represents work activity, connecting individuals aged 18 to 59 years, which make up 60% of the total population in Colombia. This work layer reflects the significant role of work in social relations, particularly in an epidemic scenario.There is a wide variety of jobs and companies, therefore it is not trivial to create a connection rule that precisely reflects the real world. Here, we consider a common scenario with random groups of sizes around [5, 30], uniformly distributed, and internally connected (such as the ''home'' layer). An example of this layer is shown on Fig. 2(b), using
post_context: .The connectivity of nodes within a group plays a vital role in determining virus transmission, as discussed in detail in Section 3.1.1. Public transportation is a crucial aspect of urban life, but it also poses a risk for the spread of epidemics due to its high population density and constant movement of vehicles. Our proposed third layer focuses on public transport systems, which cater to individuals without access to personal vehicles. In Colombia, the percentage of people using public transport varies based on city size, with 64.98% in capitals and 35.89% in other cities. On average, individuals spend around 1.2 hours a day using public transport. We consider 50% of the population from both cases to be represented in the "transports" layer, forming random groups of varying sizes between 10 and 40. Each group is fully connected, reflecting real-world situations. (Source: http://g1.globo.com/bom-dia-colombia/noticia/2015/02/colombianos-gastam-em-media-1h20-por-dia-em-transportes-publicos.html)

contents: location: rio de janeiro; time: march 5
author: enrique
pre_context: In a study published in Physica A 564 (2021), L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva, and colleagues examined the impact of various interventions on the progression of an epidemic, including fluctuations in case numbers, deaths, and hospital bed occupancy. The simulation started with a social network featuring all its layers and original infection probabilities. The outbreak began at a node with a degree closest to the network average and spread incrementally over 300 days with daily iterations. This study assumed an optimistic scenario where individuals were aware of the virus from the start, leading to an initial infection probability of β < 1.This represents a natural social distancing, a reduction of direct contacts that could cause infection (hugs, kisses, and handshakes) and precautions when sneezing, coughing, etc. We empirically found that this initial value of β yields results with a higher correlation to the Brazilian pandemic. A moderated quarantine is applied after 27 days, representing the isolation measures implemented on March 5 by most Brazilian states, such as São Paulo [39]. To simulate this quarantine, we remove the layers of religious activities and schools and reduce the contacts on transports and work down to 30% of its initial value, i.e.,
post_context: . The activities that continue on despite quarantine measures represent essential services and those being carried out with increased precautions. We examine how the β parameter impacts the overall shape of the epidemic in Fig. 4(a), showing results for different β values and their effect on daily new cases and deaths over a 300-day period. Higher infection rates lead to faster disease spread and higher case and death numbers, but the epidemic also ends sooner due to natural immunization of recovered individuals. When comparing the model's output to real data from the Brazilian epidemic up to May 18, using a β value of 0.3 closely aligns with the actual scenario where people are taking precautions. The model generally fits the data well, with some discrepancies likely due to increased testing and changing isolation levels in Brazil. The daily death toll in the model is slightly higher than official numbers, which could be attributed to underdetection rates and limited testing. Further investigation is needed to fully understand these discrepancies.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In their study published in Physica A 564 (2021), eiva et al. examined how various interventions impact the spread of an epidemic, including changes in the number of cases, deaths, and hospital bed occupancy. The research began by initializing a social network with its original layers and infection probabilities, with the virus starting at a node closest to the average network degree and spreading over 1-day iterations for up to 300 days. The study considered an optimistic scenario where individuals were aware of the virus from the start, leading to a lower initial infection probability (β < 1) due to natural social distancing practices. A moderate quarantine was implemented on day 27, mirroring measures taken by Argentine states like Buenos Aires on March 24, with certain layers of social activities removed and contact reductions in place. The impact of different β values on the epidemic's progression was then analyzed, showing a correlation to the Argentine pandemic. Higher values of β resulted in faster disease spread but also quicker epidemic cessation due to natural immunity from recovered individuals.4.1. Comparison to real data We compare the model's output in the first 83 days with real data available from the Argentine epidemic (up to May 17) [5,40–42], results are shown on Fig. 4(b). Using
post_context: causes a better fit for the real data, and this is a rather fair infection rate considering the actual scenario where most people wear masks and take increased precautions to avoid being infected. The model demonstrates a notable overall similarity within its standard deviation. The increase in diagnosed cases over the past ten days may be attributed to the rise in testing in Argentina, or possibly the consistent decline in isolation levels in the country (below 50% for most days in the past month). Our analysis assumed a steady isolation level similar to what was seen in the days following government decrees in Argentina. However, data suggests that these levels are subject to change, potentially resulting in higher numbers of diagnosed cases and deaths than indicated in this paper (refer to the "keep isolation" scenario in the next section). The average daily death toll predicted by the model is higher than the official figures, which is expected due to potential underdetection rates and limited testing. Analysis of death numbers in Argentina from January 1 to April 30, comparing 2019 and 2020 data, reveals a significant increase in deaths post-February 26, the date of the first confirmed COVID-19 case in Argentina, suggesting that the actual death toll may be significantly higher than reported. Moving forward, we discuss four potential actions to be taken after 90 days (May 26): a) Maintain current isolation levels; b) Lift isolation measures and return to normal activities; c) Resume work activities only; or d) Intensify isolation by halting work and transport activities.

author: enrique
pre_context: L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, and M.B.Neiva et al. Physica A 564 (2021) 125498 (a) Analysis of different β values and their impacts on the shape of new cases and deaths. (b) Comparison between the proposed model best Fig. 4. fit (
post_context: ) for the first 83 days (up to May 21) to 4 different data sources of the Argentinian COVID-19 numbers: EU Open Data Portal (EUODP) [40], Worldometer [41], Johns Hopkins University [5], and World Health Organization (WHO) [42].The dashed lines indicate the standard deviation, with the average over a 5-day window shown in the real data curve and the solid lines representing the actual raw data. The higher average number of deaths predicted by the proposed model may be linked to underdetection. In order to analyze the impact of COVID-19 underdetection in Argentina, we compared the official death records of 2019 and 2020 for the same period (January 1 to April 30). This comparison was made with the COVID-19 records from the WHO and the Argentine government data. Significant underdetection of COVID-19 cases may be indicated by the largest difference observed immediately after the first confirmed case. The total number of diagnosed cases and deaths in this scenario are 1,253,119 (±26,009) and 197,756 (±5,693) respectively. Implementing a strict lockdown after 90 days results in a significant decrease in infection and death counts compared to other strategies, with a quicker recovery time as well. The peak in daily new cases is on day 93 (June 1) and daily new deaths peak on day 106 (June 11). By day 300, there are 552,855 (±195,802) diagnosed cases and 87,059 (±30,871) deaths. Using the hospitalization time outlined in Fig. 3, the number of occupied beds for different cases can be estimated. Additionally, we illustrate the disparity between the growth of diagnosed and undiagnosed cases as well as recovered cases.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In a recent study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. published in Physica A 564 (2021), Figure 7 shows the total number of infected and recovered cases and the evolution of hospital bed utilization in three possible scenarios after 90 days (May 26): (a) Maintaining current isolation levels (no schools or religious gatherings, reduced work and public transport), (b) Ending isolation (returning schools, religious gatherings, work, and public transport to normal), or (c) Increasing isolation (stopping work and public transport). Testing capacity is limited by either a small number of available tests or the rapid spread of the virus that outpaces testing capacity. The study assumed that only hospitalized cases and 20% of mild cases are diagnosed.Asymptomatic cases are not diagnosed and keep acting normally in the network, considering the active layers. Regarding the isolation of infected nodes, we take some optimistic assumptions: Mild cases (even those not diagnosed) are aware of its symptoms and isolate themselves at home. Severe and critical cases are eventually hospitalized, and then fully isolated from the network (removal of all its edges). Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and
post_context: , representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures).After 27 days of the first confirmed case, initial isolation measures were implemented, including the suspension of schools and religious activities, while work and transportation continued at 30% of their normal capacity, achieved by reducing the β term. After 90 days from the first case, various options were considered: maintaining current isolation levels, increasing isolation, ending isolation and returning to normal at 100%, or only allowing work activities to resume. Results indicate that maintaining current isolation levels could lead to prolonged spread, reaching an estimated peak around June 5 with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and 1,900 daily new deaths. By the end of the year, there could be approximately 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3.6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths. Hospitals may exceed capacity around June 11, but efficient implementation of new ICU beds and patient management strategies could help control the situation. However, this relies on the optimistic assumption that social isolation remains above 50%, as was initially observed during the Argentinian quarantine. Currently, social isolation levels in Argentina are consistently around 12%.

author: chunwei
pre_context:
In a study published in Physica A, researchers analyzed three potential scenarios for the COVID-19 pandemic after 90 days. These scenarios included maintaining current isolation measures, ending isolation measures, or increasing isolation measures. Testing limitations were a key factor, as testing capacity was restricted by both the number of available tests and the speed of virus spread. The study assumed that only hospitalized cases and 20% of mild cases were diagnosed, while asymptomatic cases continued to spread the virus unknowingly in the community. The researchers also made optimistic assumptions about infected individuals voluntarily isolating themselves at home if they had mild symptoms, while severe cases would be hospitalized and effectively isolated from the population.

Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and β = 0.3, representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and
post_context:
, and an average of 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3.6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths until the end of the year.

Hospitals could potentially surpass their maximum capacity around June 11 in this situation. Nonetheless, effectively adding new ICU beds and efficiently managing patient logistics could help to control the situation. However, this optimistic outlook is based on the assumption that maintaining isolation levels above 50%, as seen at the start of the Peruvian quarantine, will continue. Presently, Peru's social isolation levels are consistently at 12%.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In a study published in Physica A 564 in 2021, researchers analyzed three possible scenarios for the evolution of COVID-19 cases and hospital bed utilization after 90 days. The scenarios included maintaining isolation measures, ending isolation measures, or increasing isolation measures. The researchers noted that testing was limited due to a low number of tests or the rapid spread of the virus. Only hospitalization cases and 20% of mild cases were assumed to be diagnosed, while asymptomatic cases were not tested. The study made optimistic assumptions about infected individuals isolating themselves, with mild cases staying home and severe cases being hospitalized and removed from the network. Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and β = 0.3, representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of
post_context: and 1900 daily new deaths, and an average of 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3,6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths until the end of the year. In this situation, hospitals could reach full capacity by June 11. Yet, by adding new ICU beds and effectively managing patient logistics, the situation could remain manageable. However, this is based on the assumption that social isolation remains above 50%, as seen at the start of the Colombian quarantine [43]. Currently, Colombia's social isolation rates are only at 12%, highlighting the challenge of maintaining control.

author: chunwei
pre_context:
In a study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. published in Physica A 564 in 2021, researchers analyzed the impact of various scenarios on the spread of infections after 90 days. The scenarios included maintaining isolation measures, lifting isolation restrictions, or increasing isolation efforts. The researchers found that testing limitations, such as a low number of tests or rapid spread of the virus, made it difficult to accurately diagnose cases. As a result, only hospitalization cases and 20% of mild cases were considered in the analysis. Asymptomatic cases were not included, assuming they continued to interact in the network. The study also made optimistic assumptions about infected individuals self-isolating at home if they experienced symptoms, and severe cases being hospitalized and isolated from the network.

Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and β = 0.3, representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and 1900 daily new deaths, and an average of
post_context:
(up to 3,6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths until the end of the year.

By June 11th, hospitals could potentially surpass their maximum capacity in this situation. Yet, with the effective addition of new ICU beds and skilled management of patient logistics, there is potential to maintain control. However, it is important to note that this optimistic outlook is based on the definition of "keep isolation" as social isolation levels being above 50%, as seen at the start of the Argentine quarantine [43]. Currently, social isolation in Argentina remains at around 12%.

author: chunwei
pre_context: L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. in Physica A 564 (2021) studied the total number of infected and recovered cases, along with the evolution of hospital bed utilization in three scenarios after 90 days (May 26): maintaining current isolation measures, ending isolation, or increasing isolation. Testing remains limited due to a low number of tests and spread velocity. Only hospitalization cases and 20% of mild cases are diagnosed, while asymptomatic cases continue to interact in the network. Assumptions include mild cases isolating at home, severe cases being hospitalized, and critical cases being fully isolated from the network. Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and β = 0.3, representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days of the first confirmed case, the first isolation measures are taken where schools and religious activities are stopped, while work and transports keep functioning at 30% of the initial capacity (achieved further reducing the β term). Different actions are then considered after 90 days of the first case: keep the current isolation levels, increase isolation, end isolation returning all activities to 100%, or returning only the work activities. The results show that keeping approximately the current isolation levels results in a prolonged propagation, as we are near the estimated peak (around June 5) with an average of 11,000 daily new cases and 1900 daily new deaths, and an average of 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3,6 million infected) and
post_context: until the end of the year. Based on current projections, hospitals could reach full capacity by June 11. However, by adding more ICU beds and effectively managing patient logistics, the situation could still be manageable.  It is important to note that this optimistic view assumes that social isolation levels remain above 50%, as they were at the start of the Argentinian quarantine. Currently, social isolation rates in Argentina are at 12%.
